content:
Are you passionate about mathematics and computing?
We invite applications for up to 3 positions, one of them at the Lagrange Mathematics & Computing Research Center (LMCRC) in Paris and the other ones in London.
In each case, the position will focus on the formalization of Grothendieck topos theory in Lean and you will collaborate with Laurent Lafforgue and myself, as well as with our internal and external collaborators, e.g. at the Istituto Grothendieck led by Olivia Caramello.

Position Details:

  • Role: Research Engineer
  • Duration: fixed-term (flexible)
  • Starting date: flexible

Areas of Interest:

  • Formalization/Interactive Theorem Proving, previous experience with a proof assistant is advantageous.
  • Grothendieck Topos Theory

Why Join Us?

  • Work alongside researchers in an international, collaborative and intellectually stimulating environment.
  • Contribute to groundbreaking research at the intersection of mathematics and computation.

Application Process:
Please email anthony[dot]bordg[at]huawei[dot]com with:

  • A brief statement of your motivation.
  • Some details about your background wrt the aforementioned areas of interest.
  • Attach your résumé if you have one.

I feel compelled to post a link to the op'ed some colleagues and I published in Le Monde 3 years ago.
It is in French but the title says “We ask researchers not to participate to the activities of the Huawei Research Center in Paris”.

Huawei published a “droit de réponse” on June 7, 2021.

LeMonde-20210518.pdf
https://www.lemonde.fr/idees/article/2021/05/18/nous-demandons-aux-chercheurs-de-ne-pas-participer-aux-activites-du-centre-de-recherche-huawei-a-paris_6080603_3232.html

(I am not sure thumbs up/down are appropriate here. This tribune was not meant to put us in front, and while I believe it is important that, as scientists, we think together about these issues — and there are a few others that will appear sooner or later — they mustn't divide us like this. On the other hand, a few Zulip channels devoted to, say, Lean and global surveillance; Lean and energy; Lean and GAFAM, where people who wish to reflect about these questions can meet, would be welcome.)

I meant :thumbs_up: as "I believe this is useful information (including the "droit de réponse"), thank you for posting it here." But indeed turning this into a upvote/downvote battle is not the right way to have this conversation.
